title: 104_hr4110
content: The "Children Health Insurance Act of 1996" is cited as the short title. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new section on Health Insurance Availability for Children. Subtitle L--Health Insurance Availability for Children is added to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, including chapters on excise tax for failure to meet coverage requirements, access to coverage, and definitions. "Subtitle L--Health Insurance Availability for Children adds chapters on excise tax for failure to meet coverage requirements, access to coverage, and definitions, including Sec. 9901 on excise tax for failure to meet access to coverage requirement." The tax is imposed on group health plans and insurers for failing to meet coverage requirements. The tax amount is 25 percent of each premium received for group health plans. The tax imposed on group health plans and insurers for not meeting coverage requirements is 25 percent of each premium received. If the group health plan is self-insured, the cost of coverage for participants and beneficiaries is considered. The tax imposed on group health plans and insurers for not meeting coverage requirements is 25 percent of each premium received. For self-insured plans, the cost of coverage for participants and beneficiaries is considered. The tax imposed on insurers offering individual health insurance coverage is 25 percent of the total premiums paid for the plan year in case of failure. There are limitations on the tax amount if the failure is not discovered. The tax imposed on insurers for individual health insurance coverage is 25 percent of total premiums paid for the plan year in case of failure. There are limitations on the tax amount if the failure is not discovered through reasonable diligence. No tax imposed if failure was not known through reasonable diligence. No tax if failure corrected within 30 days due to reasonable cause, not willful neglect. No tax imposed if failure was due to reasonable cause, not willful neglect, and corrected within 30 days. Waiver possible for failures due to reasonable cause, not willful neglect. The tax imposed under subsection (a) may be waived by the Secretary if the failure is due to reasonable cause and not willful neglect. This section does not apply to governmental plans. The tax imposed by subsection (a) can be waived if payment would be excessive relative to the failure. This section does not apply to governmental or church plans. The responsible party for the tax varies depending on the type of plan. The tax imposed by subsection (a) can be waived if payment would be excessive relative to the failure. This section does not apply to governmental or church plans. The responsible party for the tax varies depending on the type of plan, with the group health plan or insurer offering health insurance coverage being liable. "Requirement of access to coverage under SEC. 9902." Each group health plan must offer qualifying coverage for qualifying young dependents of participants. The offer must be made when a person first becomes a qualifying young dependent and annually thereafter. Similarly, insurers in the individual market must offer qualifying coverage for individuals under 21 years of age. Each insurer in the individual market must offer qualifying coverage for individuals under 21 years of age, residing in the US, and a citizen, national, or alien permanently residing in the US. Qualifying coverage includes health care benefits without limitations based on pre-existing conditions. The section defines "qualifying coverage" as health care benefits that include Medicare benefits without limitations based on pre-existing conditions or waiting periods. The section defines "qualifying coverage" as health care benefits that include Medicare benefits without any waiting period for coverage, with coinsurance limits set for part B services. The section outlines coinsurance limits for part B services, ensuring that the coinsurance does not exceed $10 or 10 percent of the recognized payment amount for the item or service provided. Well child care benefits are also covered without deductibles or coinsurance. Payment for newborn and well-baby care, pediatrician services for high-risk deliveries, and well-child care is covered without deductibles, coinsurance, or copayments. Newborn and well-baby care, pediatrician services for high-risk deliveries, well-child care, routine office visits, immunizations, laboratory tests, and preventive dental care are covered without copayments. The Secretary, in consultation with the American Academy of Pediatrics, will establish a periodicity schedule for well-child care services, including routine office visits, immunizations, laboratory tests, and preventive dental care. The Secretary, in consultation with the American Academy of Pediatrics, will establish a periodicity schedule for well-child care services to ensure appropriate frequency. Managed care is permitted as long as there is reasonable access to benefits. Qualifying young dependents are defined for this section. The term 'qualifying young dependent' refers to an individual under 21 years old, residing in the US, a citizen or national (or alien permanently residing in the US under color of law), and a dependent as defined in section 152. The term 'qualifying young dependent' is defined as an individual under 21 years old, residing in the US, a citizen or national, and a dependent as defined in section 152. In this chapter, the term 'group health plan' is defined as per section 5000(b)(1), excluding plans with medical benefits limited to coverage in paragraph (2)(B). 'Health insurance coverage' refers to benefits for medical care under hospital or medical service policies. The term 'health insurance coverage' includes medical care benefits under various policies or contracts offered by insurers or health maintenance organizations, excluding coverage for specific services under separate policies. The term 'health insurance coverage' includes medical care benefits under policies or contracts offered by insurers or health maintenance organizations, excluding coverage for specific services under separate policies. This excludes coverage for accident, credit-only, vision, disability income, long-term care, nursing home care, community-based care dental, on-site medical clinics, or employee assistance programs. The term 'health insurance coverage' includes Medicare supplemental health insurance and similar supplemental coverage provided under a group health plan. Medicare supplemental health insurance, supplemental coverage under a group health plan, liability insurance supplements, general and automobile liability insurance, workers' compensation insurance. The curr_chunk lists various types of insurance coverage, including liability insurance, workers' compensation, automobile medical-payment insurance, coverage for specified diseases, and hospital indemnity insurance. The curr_chunk specifies additional types of insurance coverage, such as hospital indemnity insurance, short-term limited duration insurance, and other comparable coverage as determined by regulations. The curr_chunk defines health maintenance organization as a federally qualified organization under the Public Health Service Act. The curr_chunk defines a health maintenance organization as a federally qualified organization under the Public Health Service Act or a similar organization recognized or regulated under State law for solvency. The curr_chunk further defines an insurer as an insurance company, service, or organization licensed to engage in insurance business in a State. The term 'insurer' refers to an insurance company, service, or organization licensed to engage in insurance business in a State. The term 'individual market' refers to the market for health insurance coverage offered to individuals, excluding coverage offered to employers or through a group health plan. The term 'individual market' refers to health insurance coverage for individuals, not employers or group health plans. It does not include coverage issued by insurers based on association affiliation. Definitions for 'beneficiary' and 'participant' are incorporated from the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. A clerical amendment is made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Subtitle L. Health Insurance Availability for Children. The requirement of section 9902 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 shall take effect on January 1, 1998, and apply to coverage offered on or after that date. Refundable tax credit for purchase of health coverage for children. SEC. 35 introduces a refundable tax credit for purchasing health coverage for children. A tax credit of 80% of qualified health premiums paid by an individual is allowed against the tax imposed for the taxable year. The credit is applied at a rate of $0.50 for each $1 of tax liability. The tax credit is applied at a rate of $0.50 for each $1 of tax liability, which is the excess of the tax imposed for the taxable year and the taxpayer's social security taxes. The tax credit is calculated by subtracting the sum of the tax imposed for the taxable year and the taxpayer's social security taxes from the credit allowed under section 32. The term 'social security taxes' refers to the taxes imposed on amounts received by the taxpayer during the calendar year, minus the credit allowed under section 32 for the taxable year. The term 'social security taxes' for any taxpayer in a taxable year includes taxes on received amounts, half of self-employment taxes, and half of certain other taxes. The term 'social security taxes' includes half of self-employment taxes and half of certain other taxes for a taxpayer in a taxable year. The term 'social security taxes' excludes taxes eligible for a special refund under section 6413(c) and payments made under agreements with foreign affiliates under section 3121(l). The term 'qualified health premium' refers to the amount paid for health coverage of a qualifying young dependent. Amounts paid under agreements with foreign affiliates equivalent to social security taxes can be treated as such taxes under section 6413(c). For tax purposes, the term 'qualified health premium' refers to the amount paid for health coverage of a qualifying young dependent. Health coverage includes insurance that meets specific criteria, and a qualifying young dependent is defined accordingly. The term 'health coverage' refers to insurance that includes qualifying coverage. A 'qualifying young dependent' is defined as per specific criteria. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections. The amendments in this section relate to the purchase of health coverage for children and overpayments of tax, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 1997.
